sp.p: Heed not for me— fly, Adrienne, to safety, and for life.

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: Cowards! will none stir? Rochet forgets no duty, betrays no trust; Savignie—Captain, you refuse her arrest, then I —(SOLDIERS advance, L.)

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: (who during the confusion has obtained and loaded a musket, R.) Monsieur Rochet, the quiver of a nerve, a movement of these soldiers, and pray for your soul, for that instant you are a dead man. (levelling at him—Picture)

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: Stay, Scarrotta! Victor Savignie, in the face of a sure death we breathe no lie—these hands are clean of crime; believe that, believe too that I would be tortured to a thousand deaths, rather than one hair of your head should be injured for my sake. Soldiers, fall in—I come, Monsieur Rochet, I come. (descending to him) Say, Victor, do I love you now? (by this time she is in the midst of the group)

sp.speaker: Savig.
sp.p: Whither do you go?

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: For your sake, to my death at Montauban. March. (soft music—Picture of their preparing to start, and closed in)

div.head: SCENE SECOND. —A Street in Montauban.
div.stage: Enter BERTRAND, R., his left arm bound up.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p:
Courage, Bertrand, courage; the cut is nothing. 'Tis the cold—the bitter cold—which bites into my tropic
nature. Scarotta wounded—his band dispersed—and, God of my fathers! my young mistress, Adrienne, alone 'mid the snow-clad hills!

div.stage: Enter M. THIBAUT, L., and crosses.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Pardon, Monsieur, I am a stranger at Montauban. Can you inform me where a poor man, like myself, can obtain provision and a lodging for the night?

sp.speaker: Thibaut.
sp.p: If you be honest, there, at the Widow Manette's, where you see the lamp swinging—but if you if you—

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Be not honest, you were about to say—

sp.speaker: Thibaut.
sp.p: Then had you better quit the town. Sous-Prefet Rochet is very strict upon travellers.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: I have heard his name; but I do not fear him, monsieur. (going) What, pray you, are those lights there? (pointing)

sp.speaker: Thibaut.
sp.p: The Court of the Procureur-General.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Do they sit so late?

sp.speaker: Thibaut.
sp.p: Know you not this was the very nest of rebels or patriots, as each has been in turn called by the Empire or the Directory? 'Tis the Empire now, so "Vive L'Empereur!"

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Are there then so many prisoners to try?

sp.speaker: Thibaut.
sp.p: The sous-Prefet provides plenty of food for the galleys or the guillotine. This time it is no political prisoner for whose blood he thirsts, 'tis a girl charged with murder.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: A girl charged with—with murder! Oh! stay, monsieur, was it murder by—by poison.

sp.speaker: Thibaut.
sp.p: Yes! now I remember it, Yes!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: And her name? do you happen to recollect her name?

sp.speaker: Thibaut.
sp.p: If I heard it, I think I—

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Is it that of a lady of Beaupré, — Adrienne?

sp.speaker: Thibaut.
sp.p: Yes! Ah, that was it, Adrienne. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Adrienne—stay, am I sure, am I certain—was it a breath of fancy, or reality, Adrienne—It was—mercy! mercy Heaven on my breaking heart. For me let the past be past. But, Adrienne, for thee is a future yet a future which my death shall shape, and which thy innocence shall crown. Exit L.

div.stage: Enter GIANNETTA, leading SCARROTTA, R.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: It's head in the lion's mouth, Giannetta, and though I know it well I care not; I'll just in, to hear what that rascal Rochet has to say. You are a good daughter; she was ever kind to you—and hang it, spite of my leg, I'll hobble to that den of thieves; I may be useful to her.

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: Now, father, you're such a temper, you're always flying out about something or other; or if—

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: My temper's as sweet as an angel's, as long as I have my own way.

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: Oh, don't I take after my father!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Stay you here, child, while I trouble that cabaret there for a drop of eau de vie, the true spiritual water of life.

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: I'll accompany you, father!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What I !—I allow a child of mine to enter a common public house!

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: Well, father, I haven't so great an objection when there's anything good to be got there; but do not stay long.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Fear not for me. By this time our band have delivered their prisoners, and I am free. See there! (a drum march is heard very piano) There is mademoiselle—noble Savignie, his hand is on hers, his arm supports her sinking form—a moment, Giannetta, a moment, my child, and then ——Exit, L.

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: And then—yes that's it, and then—what then? alas! my poor mistress, my very soul weeps for her; to day free among the mountains, to-night upon her trial, and to-morrow, oh, heaven! I shudder to think of to-morrow; and I so lonely. Oh, if only Hector(as she is going off L., she meets HECTOR —she runs away, R. HECTOR getting C., sees her, and runs away, L.—when both are at the wings they stop)

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: She's a lovely woman.

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: After all he's better than nobody.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: She's got such a commanding way with her.

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: He's an uncommon fine man in his uniform.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Giannetta! (coughs and sneezes)

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: Hector! (coughs and sneezes)

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: I never said I didn't love you, Giannetta.

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: You never shewed you did, Hector.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Don't let us bring up the doorstep, Giannetta.

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: Don't bring up the doorstep, and why shouldn't we bring up the doorstep?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Because that was a thing I never could swallow.

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: Of course if you have any objection to take part in the household work, there's nothing more to be said.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Good-bye! (approaching her)

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: Good-bye! (approaching him)

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Farewell! (approaching her)

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: Farewell! (approaching him)

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: And for ever. (approaching her)

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: Fare thee well. (approaching him)

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Oh! (starting to wing)

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: O-oh! (going to wing)

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Giannetta!

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: Hector !

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Oh—nothing!

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: That's what you're always talking about.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: (aside) If she was only half as fond of me as she is of her father, I shouldn't have such a bad berth after all.

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: What were you observing, Hector?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Bracing weather!

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: It's good embracing weather; what then?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Nothing!

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: O-h!

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: I was a thinking

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: Dear me, is it possible?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: I was a thinking whether we'd forgive one another and be happy once more.

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: It rests with yourself, Hector; will you clean that doorstep?

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Oh, ain't it a bitter pill! Well there then, since you make such a point of it, I will. Father will buy me off.

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: Oh, Hector, you have got such a tongue.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Say wilt thou be mine, my own?

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: My sweet! (they rush to embrace, the drum intervenes)

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: Embrace me!

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: Wait a minute—try it again. (they return to their places)

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: My own!

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: My sweet! (the drum intervenes) Wait a minute. (GIANNETTA shifts the drum) Now try it.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: My own!

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: My sweet. (embrace and exit, R.)

div.head: SCENE THIRD. — The Court at Montauban.
div.stage: On an elevation, L., the PRESIDENT is discovered, seated the JURY sit against the flat, between him and the Audience—BERTRAND, SCAROTTA, and GIANNETTA among the CROWD at the back— in the front of the PRESIDENT, a small table with papers, at which ROCHET is seated, R. C. a small enclosed bar for ADRIENNE—SAVIGNIE, R. GENDARMES, SOLDIERS, &c., C. —a small bar for the WITNESSES—a roll of drums—piano.

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: Gendarmes, lead in the accused. (drum—piano) Enter ADRIENNE, R., guarded—she is conducted to the bar—the GENDARMES form around her.

sp.speaker: Savig.
sp.p: (as she passes) Adrienne!

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: Do not weep, Savignie; I am happy.

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: Monsieur le Prefet, read the act of acccusation.

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p:
(rising) "Tis very brief, Monsieur, le President.
(reading) "The accused, known hitherto as Adrienne de Beaupré"—

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: (starting) Can he have discovered?

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: Hitherto known? (whispering, &c., through the Court)

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: In a few moments, Monsieur le President, I shall have the honour to explain. (again reading) "The accused, known hitherto as Adrienne de Beaupré, is charged with the slow murder by poison of the deceased Eugene de Grassac." (putting down the paper) The proofs are clear beyond a doubt. In the first place——

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: All things in their order. Accused—your name! (pause) Again, I ask your name.

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: (hesitatingly) Adrienne de Beaupré.

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: A moment, Monsieur le President, while I ask this woman by what right she dare assume that title—

sp.speaker: Savig.
sp.p: (starting forward) Monsieur, I—

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: (aside to him) Victor, my—my beloved, be—be still.

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: I must request the Captain Savignie to forbear an interference with the functions of the Civil Court.

sp.speaker: Savig.
sp.p: Your pardon, Monsieur le President. I will strive to be patient.

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: Once more I would ask this woman by what right she dare call herself Adrienne de Beaupré?

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: (aside) Never! never! They can but slay me; and never shall my lips open upon that.

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: To spare the time of the Court, I would merely ask the accused to explain the nature of these papers, (shewing the three papers formerly shewn by DE GRASSAC) found amongst the effects of the deceased.

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: (aside) Horrible! horrible!

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: Still silent! I would respectfully entreat the Court to remember the dates of each. The first—18th July, 1795— a certificate of the marriage of Emile de Martres, afterwards Count de Beaupré, at Pisa, to one Mina Scarotta. The second, on the 21st November in the same year, also a certificate of marriage of the same Emile de Martres at Paris to Stephanie de Saint Croix.

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: My mother!

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: The third and last. Also a certificate, but this time of a death, it is dated 14th October, 1796, of the death of Mina Scarotta—the first, and only legal wife—the real Madame de Martres. On the face of these facts, I ask the court whether she (pointing to ADRIENNE), ne'er born in wedlock, speaks rightfully, when she dares to call herself by her father's name. (ADRIENNE stands as transfixed—movement and chat in court)

sp.speaker: Savig.
sp.p: Speak—whisper—or even sigh! this silence will make ye mad.

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: Stone I am, Victor, only stone.

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: Shall I put these documents into court, or will you spare me that necessity by the confession of the truth?

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: Yes, it's true—it is true !

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: And you have known this for some time?

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: Yes, Monsieur le President, yes. Amongst my father's papers, at his death, the eyes of my poor mother rested on the proofs of her own dishonour, and—and—of mine! When she herself was going to to Paradise, she made me swear to her never—never to reveal this secret, and through suffering and through sorrow, I have kept my oath.

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: And the large revenues you inherited, which were not yours——which you stole—where are they?

sp.speaker: Savig.
sp.p: (C.) Ask the poor, Monsieur Rochet, and you will hear of honesty enriched—ask those who were weakly, and whom her charities have made strong—ask of Heaven, and it will tell you of good deeds gathered there, which shall be as crowns of joy in that long hereafter which waits her panting soul.

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: Quick, father.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Child, I'm bursting. (coming forward) Stay, Monsieur le President!

sp.speaker: Gian.
sp.p: Father will get hanged; I know he will.

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: Your name?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Jacopo Scarrotta.

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: Your country?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Italy.

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: Your profession?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: E'en a patriot.

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: Brigand!

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: As you please. I doubt not but that you know more about brigands than patriots, Monsieur Rochet.

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: What have you to say?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p:
The truth. Courage, Adrienne! 'twas not your mother; 'twas this poor child! (taking out miniature)—for heaven help her, she was but a child—who, by a false vow was lured to a mock marriage. Two officers of the army of Italy came to our peaceful home, their names, Emile de Martres and Eugene de Grassac; De Martres won my trusting sister's love, and a union, though in secret, was to consecrate her devotion. But few days past ere her husband, for she thought him such, left her, and after months of weary waiting, she heard that he was married to another; she, poor girl, journeyed to Paris— saw him, and showed him the certificate of her marriage; he crushed her heart with a smile and a sneer! 'twas a false
priest, 'twas his comrade, De Grassac. My dead Mina was the victim, and your mother, Adrienne, was the lawful wife of Emile de Martres!

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: How through this storm of sorrow bursts the flood of joy! Mother, could I but see your face—could I but touch your hand—oh! mother, mother, look down upon and bless me !

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: A providential revelation, which at once supplies the motive. Eugene de Grassac knew then of this secret !

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: Oh, monsieur, I am in such a dream of happiness. Joy with my joy, Victor, be glad as I am glad!

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: Accused, have you forgotten that your life is the stake at issue?

sp.speaker: Savig.
sp.p: Adrienne, for my sake—

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: De Grassac knew of this secret—yes; and threatened its revelation.

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: And you were his nurse, his constant attendant during his illness?

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: I was—alas—

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: I would wish the Court to note the frequent opportunities that must accompany such close association. I believe, too, you entertained something warmer than a mere passing attachment for that young officer by your side. You cast down your eyes—'tis a sufficient reply. The object of the assassin becomes doubly clear. Dr. Theodore Leroux.

div.stage: Enter LEROUX, R., he bows to the PRESIDENT, and passes at once to the witness bar.

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: Monsieur, your name—

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: You may spare the preliminary questions. Dr. Theodore Leroux is well known as one of the most skilful physicians in France. (bowing to LEROUX)

sp.speaker: Leroux.
sp.p: (bowing) Monsieur le President.

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: You were acquainted with the deceased Eugene de Grassac?

sp.speaker: Leroux.
sp.p: I was.

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: And conducted, I believe, the medical examination after his death? (LEROUX bows) In your opinion he died from the effects of poison. (LEROUX bows) Can you tell its nature?

sp.speaker: Leroux.
sp.p: I cannot. I never saw the like symptoms before. It was by some deadly vegetable poison, at present unknown In Europe.

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: (to ADRIENNE) Have you any question to ask the Doctor?

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: None, monsieur, none.

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: Proceed, M. Rochet.

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p:
With due respect to the Court, it appears to me there is little more to be said. The evidence of Dr. Leroux
shews the crime—the confession of the accused, the motive. In the name of the law, I demand the life of the accused. (CROWD whisper)

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: (coming forward) Pardon, Monsieur le President. Pardon, Monsieur le Prefet. Is there not one formality omitted? May not the accused present a witness as important for example as myself?

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: Your name?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Bertrand. I was a slave when I was bought by the Count de Beaupré; and in Martinique they give slaves but one name.

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: Your occupation?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: I was formerly steward to that lady, Mademoiselle Adrienne, so wronged and yet so innocent.

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: You say innocent?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: I say innocent, because I know the name of the really guilty.

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: Perhaps, then, you will reveal it.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: I am here for that purpose—it is my own.

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: Bertrand! (movement all rise and BERTRAND is surrounded by GENDARMES)

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Be silent, mistress most beloved! I would have heaped a blessing, and it has been transformed into a curse.

sp.speaker: Rochet.
sp.p: We have read of the romantic attachments of the South. May not this man, in order to screen his mistress, have taken on himself the consequences of her crime?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: I had anticipated the objection, and am prepared to overcome it. Dr. Leroux was anxious to know the nature of the poison which destroyed De Grassac: it is here. (taking out small bottle) Colourless, you perceive; and, as I understand, tasteless. By minute doses destruction is slow; but when, for example, a quantity like this is taken—(drinking it—movement) —then——

sp.speaker: Leroux.
sp.p: Then—

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: "Tis an affair of seconds, Dr. Leroux—I die no shameful death! If on my body you find the same symptoms as those of De Grassac, will you then believe her innocent?

sp.speaker: Presid.
sp.p: We must, perforce, admit it. (the GUARDS release ADRIENNE)

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Then I die—happy! Oh! mistress, pity me—pray for me! (falls)

sp.speaker: Savig.
sp.p: Adrienne !

sp.speaker: Adrien.
sp.p: (slowly tottering to his arms) Victor—husband! (Picture)
